title: 103_hr1013
content: The Act titled "Expedited Consideration of Proposed Rescissions Act of 1993" amends the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 to allow for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions. The "Expedited Consideration of Proposed Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act by transmitting a special message to Congress within 3 days of the Act's enactment. The proposed rescission cannot be repeated under this section or another specified section. The "Expedited Consideration of Proposed Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act by transmitting a special message to Congress within 3 days of the Act's enactment. The President must send a separate special message for each subcommittee of the Committee on Appropriations if the Act includes accounts within the jurisdiction of multiple subcommittees. The special message must specify the budget authority proposed to be rescinded and is subject to limitations on the amount that can be rescinded. The "Expedited Consideration of Proposed Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority by transmitting a special message to Congress. The amount that can be rescinded for a particular program, project, or activity is limited to 25 percent of the amount appropriated in that Act. The procedures for expedited consideration require the introduction of a draft bill within two days of receiving the special message. The "Expedited Consideration of Proposed Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority by transmitting a special message to Congress. The bill introduced in the House of Representatives must be referred to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report the bill without substantive revision within seven days. If the committee fails to do so, it will be automatically discharged from consideration. The "Expedited Consideration of Proposed Rescissions Act of 1993" allows any Member of the House of Representatives to move to strike proposed rescissions of budget authority with support from 49 other Members. A vote on final passage must occur within 10 days of the bill's introduction, and if passed, it is transmitted to the Senate. A motion to proceed to consideration of the bill is highly privileged and not debatable in the House of Representatives. The "Expedited Consideration of Proposed Rescissions Act of 1993" allows any Member of the House of Representatives to move to strike proposed rescissions of budget authority with support from 49 other Members. A motion to proceed to consideration of the bill is highly privileged and not debatable. Debate on a bill under this section shall not exceed 4 hours, divided equally between those favoring and opposing the bill. Appeals from decisions of the Chair relating to the application of the Rules of the House of Representatives shall be decided without debate. The procedure for a bill under this section shall be decided without debate. Consideration of a bill under this section shall be governed by the Rules of the House of Representatives. A bill transmitted to the Senate shall be referred to its Committee on Appropriations, which must report the bill without substantive revision within seven days of receiving it. Failure to report the bill within this period will result in automatic discharge from consideration. During consideration, any Senator can move to strike proposed rescissions of budget authority with support from 14 others. A vote on final passage must occur within 10 days of transmission to the Senate. If passed without amendment, the bill is returned to the House. If amended in the Senate, an engrossed amendment is sent back to the House. Upon receipt of an engrossed amendment from the Senate, the House of Representatives shall be deemed to have agreed to the Senate amendment, and the bill shall be enrolled by the Clerk of the House. A motion in the Senate to proceed to consider a bill under this section is privileged and not debatable. Debate in the Senate on a bill under this section shall not exceed 10 hours, divided between the majority and minority leaders or their designees. Debate in the Senate on any debatable motion or appeal in connection with a bill under this section shall be limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the manager of the bill. The minority leader or designee controls the time in opposition to the motion. Additional time can be allotted by the leaders during consideration of motions. Further limiting debate on a bill is not debatable, and a motion to recommit a bill is not allowed. No amendments or divisions allowed for bills under this section. Budget authority proposed for rescission must be available for obligation the day after the bill is defeated. The bill transmitted with a special message includes definitions for "appropriation Act" and "continuity of a session of either House of Congress." Section 904 of the Act is amended to include sections 1013 and 1018 in the exercise of rulemaking powers. The bill includes amendments to sections 1011, 1014, 1017, and 1018 of the Act, as well as changes to section 1015 regarding references to specific sections. Section 1016 is also amended to include the insertion of "1014" in various subsections. The bill amends sections 1011, 1014, 1017, and 1018 of the Act, with changes to section 1015 and the insertion of "1014" in section 1016 subsections. Additionally, clerical amendments are made to the table of sections, redesignating items and inserting new items. Section 1013 of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 expedites consideration of certain proposed rescissions. It applies to budget authority provided by appropriation Acts enacted during the One Hundred Third Congress and terminates when Congress adjourns sine die in 1994.
